15 games, 748. How is this so high on BGG I’ll never know. There was a lot of hype for me which may have ruined my experience because the game is simply mediocre. Very expensive game for only 15 plays(about 10-12 hours), no replayability and no resellability is bad enough on its own. Now about the game - the story was presented very good in the first 8/12 (8 months), I was really impressed actually, especially with the sticker stuff and box oppenings. After that the story went straight downhill, becoming mediocre and plain stupid at times with the least interesting ending ever. It was super easy to miss/accidentally change a rule here-or-there and there is absolutely no way to fix the mistake or replay the game - almost every month we did something wrong... We quickly saw our mistakes, and they were about 50/50 bad/good making the game very easy/insanely hard at times but still it makes you wonder what it should have been!

I really think if this was a two-year game (24-48 games) for the same prise tag (or a few bucks more) they could have made the story much much better with super cool ending and with more time to have small mistakes matter less. Instead we have this - extremely overpriced, anti-climating, unsellable, unresettable piece of cardboard, I’m very dissapointed!

Having said that - the first 8 out of the 12 months of the game were actually pretty fun but I still can’t recommend this to anyone (...or give/gift my copy to anyone...)

The first few months were a lot of fun, Pandemic with mild rule twists and upgrades that kept us playing. But around the "May" objectives it turned into a disaster of a game.

The problems ranged ranged from simple things that were just annoying to major gameplay problems. Some simple things: **Instructions out of order (It would say "read instructions 17, 36, 41, and 12) and you'd have to try and find them.
**Scratch off pieces, like on lotto scratchers, that are entirely unnecessary and create a mess
**Game designed to have no replay value - using stickers instead of replaying pieces (not that I'd want to replay this, nor would I impose a game this bad on a friend, but still, it's the thought that counts)

Major Gameplay problems:
**Some levels were designed to be unwinnable. My wife and I play normal pandemic on the highest difficulty level and win about 80% of the time. Here, when we hit May we lost. We tried replaying the level (just for "fun", not for the legacy element) using different characters, different combinations of upgrades, etc. to see how we might have won, and we could not beat it. After losing many times, we recorded what we had drawn and retrospectively evaluated what we could have done differently to win, and we could not find any pathway to victory, even knowing what cards would be drawn. This was despite the fact that we had won every previous level easily, with 1 or fewer outbreaks per level.

**When you lose a level, the game gets harder, both because of new rules and challenges and because all the losses are retained. Thus, if you can't beat a level, it will only get worse from there.

***Eventually, when you lose enough, the game helps you out by giving you advantages that allow you to win easily, but it feels completely unearned. Once you get those extra bonuses, it's hard not to win. But you didn't earn them. So victory feels hollow.

*** The plot (no spoilers here) jumps the shark.

I did not like that there was little variation in over half the months, especially when you're repeatedly playing Pandemic at its core. That is, one month will introduce a new "twist" or mechanic and the next month or two will repeat that mechanic as the twist.

One mechanism introduced in fall is quite swingy and while most twists were obvious, a few did catch us by surprise in a way that felt bad toward the end due to the fatigue of playing Pandemic over and over.

We picked up the game, decided to give a try to the legacy system. I was very excited to get into a constantly evolving story where your choices have an impact on further story line developments, etc.

The main caveat I've found in practice is ironically enough the Legacy aspect, the evolving story. While the plot evolves interestingly like a TV series season, the objectives also almost always remain the same. Thus to me, the supposed strength of the game is ultimately its weakness. On one side you got the plot progressing, but at the same time you got to cure and research the same diseases every game. Talk about repetitive goals.
That took down from the overall experience for me, and quite substantially as it was the main selling point. If I have completed a cure for a disease in January, and the plot doesn't mention anything requiring it to be researched once more, then why should I have to research a cure in all months hereafter? This paradox is difficult for me to get over in a game where story line and progression, and impact on future games is key.

The other aspects of the game worked for me, and most of it is well executed. I found the box openings to be a somewhat nice occasional adrenaline rush, albeit quite gimmicky, which I can't detail without entering into spoiler territory.

Overall, kind of a let down in comparison to the love the game gets and what I expected in terms of experience. I understand that the Legacy concept was somewhat new and brought energy and changes with its play style, but my personal opinion is that it can be executed better as the concept grows. I fear an increasing amount of releases relying on the exact same concept execution without bettering it, akin to what Battle Royale has been in video games for the past year +.

Conclusion: Not entirely terrible, but for the cost, one-time usage, and somewhat sub-par storytelling and objectives evolution, I can't rate it very high.

Final comment on study of the game and conversations with the group (Status: Sleeved & resettable after initial campaign). No detailed spoilers, but ultra vague suggestions related to the structure of the campaign and ideas behind Legacy games follows:

Really disappointing as a complete campaign. Instead, play Pandemic with expansions, or find a copy of the incredible Matt Leacock 'Thunderbirds' game plus expansions if you're fortunate enough to find a copy. That's the best way to reliably (and that is a key word in regards to this game) experience Pandemic. The campaign in Pandemic Legacy: Season 1 is not very good, and the experience of it feels empty and frought with thematic/gameplay tie issues that may not have been as apparent in 2015 among the universal praise for both the game and the still new Legacy format.

Pandemic Legacy: Season 1 is great fun for the first third of the in game year, then good but a little confused and awkwardly paced for the second third, and then actively boring and empty feeling for the last third, with additional mechanics and ideas which are simply dull, too easy to measure and respond to, and take away the focus from what made Pandemic a great board game.

The game is quite bad at introducing ideas and pacing itself, at least in my group's playthrough. This is very apparent during the final third of the campaign. I am a huge fan of Pandemic (my favourite being, erm, the amazing Thunderbirds game + expansions by Matt Leacock) and have played all of the expansions, but Pandemic Legacy: Season 1 just didn't land. We didn't play perfectly, but we're experienced enough to have not lost many games, with some of those being the curse of Pandemic Luck[TM]!!! with terrible set-up infection deck draws lining up with one another, and first/second turn Epidemic draws which almost immediately triggered off an impossible to cope with chain of outbreaks.

The lack of decent writing is understandable, and a prevalent issue with most Rob Daviau Legacy games, including the ones I really like. The story relies on tried and true tropes (not a criticism, archetypes and cliche can help in many stock narratives) and the game would be slowed down by too much narrative text, but the lack of thematic or gameplay flow when elements are introduced is slightly maddening and incredibly disappointing. That is before we started to realise how dull a lot of introduced ideas were, in both story and gameplay. I'm not against brevity or emergent storytelling, but I am when that emergent story may not happen for a group due to the board state/a generally well handled campaign. The lack of a backbone in the writing hurt the game from that point.

The destruction can hide some of this as not many games feature commitment via destructive, but I believe being a relatively big board game hobbyist shows up the flaws, cracks, and broadness that has to make up for the flaws and cracks. Seafall, Charterstone, Gloomhaven, Clank Legacy, and Risk Legacy are all better as full campaigns, even with their own distinct and varied flaws.

It completely underwrites the point of a game that is meant to be played through once, and only once. I had already made most of the game resettable, but nearly half of the campaign felt pointless to the point of me not wanting to bother considering a replay in future. I appreciate Pandemic classic, and I felt fortunate that at the time (still in Grad school) I had a group that wanted to include me in their campaign of Legacy. I still feel kind of guilty about this, because this was an expensive gift from one member of the group to the other (his partner) and I think my losing interest kind of killed their momentum--I don't know if they ever finished without me. My ultimate souring on this game surprised me. The first two sessions were very exciting! It was only around session 3 or 4 that I realized it just wasn't going to happen.

The basic assumptions don't work for what I want. The game is trying to be a long-form, vaguely narrativist exercise at the campaign level, while being built of the original game's pass-fail semi-random puzzle solving at the episodic level. In order to maintain story momentum, the game will allow you to pass an episode after a certain number of failures--I can't remember if there's some kind of long-term "penalty" or what. On paper, this sounds like a good compromise. Keep the group from frustrating each other, and allow them "officially" to keep getting to the new story beats and the new toys and goodies to play with. But once we started losing, I hated it--I didn't want to move forward. It's not that I mind losing (I lose the vast majority of the time I play games!). It's that I lost any sense of what my play was supposed to mean, in the context of this game. In a narrativist RPG, either solo or with a good GM, you can meaningfully contribute to the shape of the narrative in the face of supposed mechanical "failures", since strategy or combat mechanics are not the only (or maybe even the primary!) meat of the experience. You are building a story collaboratively and flexibly, and those apparent failures can be integrated--the player might even get to make some interesting choices about how! In pandemic Legacy, the story is fine, but it's mostly a motivation for changing the game to the next successive variant in the scripted sequence of variants. In the context of a strategy boardgame, I want the addition of variants to change the meaning of the model or the way I engage with it in a way that requires a new form of mastery. I guess maybe P:L does that, but then the *fun* part of that, to me, is then having the opportunity to learn mastery over the new elements of the system, and reflect upon what that teaches me about the model. Wheras this design sort of hinges on the idea being that the fun part is getting to the next story beat and the next variant, irrespective of whether you gained fluency with the prior one. I dunno, maybe the story got really good later on, but where we were at it just wasn't enough of a reward to keep me from feeling pretty deflated.

Part of what I've tried to figure out, in retrospect, is why this bummed me out so much. In the videogame space I've played shooters and so on where I really wanted to get to the next story beat, and turning things down to easy mode might even feel acceptable to achieve that. But here, in this context, it just felt like it was missing the point.

A negative aspect here is that the game is on purpose designed to be consumable, although this would not have been necessary. The special abilities, relationsships and scars could have been cards, which you add to the ziplock bag in which you store each character. The stuff you glue on the board, can be noted in a simple table. This lengthens set-up by about 1-2 minutes. Even the stickers you apply to the player cards, could be just put into the sleeve of the respective card.
Personally I also do not like, that this game is actually easier than base pandemic. It starts with only 5 epidemic cards and you mostly only need to cure three diseases, which makes the game maybe 60 % as difficult as base pandemic at the same epidemic card count. One other thing is the pretty boring story (Zombies and a conspiracy to gain world dominance).
So overall: Base pandemic is better, this has the usual problems of campaign games, which get amplified by the game being consumable and it is mostly just Pandemic plus minor rules additions.

At the time of writing, I am two-thirds of my way into a campaign. While this game had a strong start for our group, it's flaws have become pretty obvious sadly.

The "legacy" element of the game forces you into a win% of ~50% as you play through the game. Every time you win, the next game becomes more difficult, while losing a game makes the next game easier. The system is designed such that it is extremely hard for you to win twice in a row, and when you do, it usually happens after you've lost twice in a row. So you end up in this weird cycle where you know that in order to progress by winning, you will have to lose an almost equal amount. And that is frustrating. I feel like a co-op legacy game should give you the tools to win through every single scenario it throws at you on the first try, with an escalating difficulty as you progress. That is not what this game is. PL's idea of escalating difficulty is removing powerful action cards to increase randomness.

The extra rules that the game adds as the campaign goes on have also become a bit bloated and hard to keep track of. By comparison, TTR Legacy had extra rules/minigames but they all had an end timer and only stayed around for a few games.

Played January through end of September. The game is revolutionary and masterfully designed, with tight gameplay that offers an interesting and challenging co-op experience. The campaign gradually includes additional mechanics and complexity. However, the permanent changes to the board, characters, etc., which are probably the greatest appeal to many, to me just make the anxiety of playing often greater than the enjoyment: the fear of negative events, like a city collapsing or a character getting a scar, is amplified by the knowledge that these will affect all future plays. Frustration is quite possible, especially when the random setup makes the game (almost) unwinnable, but you still need to play through to the end in damage-control mode.

While that point is a matter of preference, I think the game does have other weaknesses that make it feel overrated (how could it have been ranked no.1?!) (Thank you, Gloomhaven!). Most notably, the sense of immersion is much better realized in other games with beautiful components and illustrations (which are lacking here). Similarly, the campaign's story itself is not very engaging and is mostly driven by minimal paragraphs of flavor(less) text. While the secret components are intriguing at first, they end up feeling mostly underwhelming. E.g., I think only the April reveal was somewhat interesting in this way. I also find it hard to bring new players onboard in the middle of the campaign, especially with the fear of permanent consequences caused by learning-curve under-performance.

I think other co-op campaign-based games with increasing complexity can offer better experiences, such as the amazing Legends of Andor (LoA). I still think the Legacy model has potential, but games like LoA make me question the need for locked content, permanent changes, self-imposed non-replayability, destruction of components, etc.

This one is hard to rate. I played 3-handed solo. It was my first legacy game to play all the way through. I love the Pandemic system, I usually play solo, and I rate all of the regular games in that system an 8 or higher.

It is very much Pandemic, with some story added and mechanics progressively added over the course of the campaign (19 games, for me).

One way it felt very different from the other pandemics (for me) is the degree to which I felt I had to engage with the puzzle of choosing what characters to pair together. Typically with the pandemic games, though, I do a completely random role selection or, for the IP games, I might do one based on thematics, depending on my mood. I *never* pick and choose roles for synergies. And there are definitely games I lost and objectives I missed because of the choices I made there.

The story was uninspired but not wholly uninteresting. The lack of branching narratives started to feel like a weakness by the time I was 2/3 through the campaign, and the mechanical corrective for that** leaves me really surprised there aren’t more comments on it.

Knowing this game came out before any of the spin off games, it was interesting to see some influence on the later games. The final objective, in particular, was picked up and used extensively (and, frankly, better) in one of the spin-offs that came out after all the pandemic legacy games.

Vanilla Pandemic is swingier than most of its successors, and I think this one had points where it felt swingier than vanilla Pandemic.

I disliked that the map you start with for early January is flatter than the vanilla Pandemic map, but I loved how the map’s texture shifted after, and even during, each game. As far as I could see, that was the only thing that justified this being a legacy, one-time-through, campaign. None of the other changes are so big or frequent they couldn’t be handled through tokens, cards, &c. instead of stickers. Also, speaking of components and their necessity, scratch-offs suck.

**SPOILER
Not a story spoiler, really, but a mechanical one: the whole thing ends with a BYOS-style score chart?!? Really?!? It makes the choices you make matter, but also would skew incentives if it were known before the end. I completed all but one of the search objectives, but the one I’d didn’t complete was super unlucky for me and would have required such singular focus to complete I for sure would have lost the games it was in trying to complete it (and still might not have been able to). Not getting that objective meant -100 points for me, and I might as well have not bothered with the other search objectives, as they gained me nothing without having completed all of them. I also was denied 80 points because I left one of the things for those points untouched (because it was on a level 5 city), and got no credit for dealing with all of the others (though at least dealing with them made one of the final objectives easier, so it wasn’t useless the way the search objectives were).

I enjoyed the journey, even if the destination left me a little cold. The BYOS chart I dislike (there are some games I enjoy solo despite being BYOS, but not many) and the final two objectives for December were meh for me. December was actually the least interesting of the twelve months, I thought. I like Pandemic a lot, and I’m glad I played through this, and maybe I’ll even do seasons 2 and 0 but, owning all of the regular Pandemic games (as I do), I didn’t feel this to be an especially unique or interesting take on it (although I appreciate that that may have been different in 2015 compared with 2025). And, after 19 games played over less than two weeks, it is done and can never be pulled out again. That is a knock against it. I own plenty of games I haven’t played 20 times, or for a total of 20-25 hours. But the fact that this was one officially done, forever, and unable to be passed on or re-sold, doesn’t feel great. Especially since it didn’t wow me.

The Pandemic Legacy games are still the best legacy games there are. It's amazing they came out so early and nailed it. I love regular Pandemic and the legacy version is even better. Even though Pandemic has the risk that a bad starting shuffle could wreck a game. Its strength is that you need to be clever to do well, and switch up your strategies as the game changes, which it does in big ways despite always following the basics of Pandemic. Your decisions feel incredibly meaningful. The fact that it is fully cooperative really helps. A lot of legacy games that aren't fully cooperative have to make changes that aren't so meaningful to avoid throwing off the balance of the game, or they do throw off the balance of the game and aren't fun to play as a campaign. Without giving much away, as you play Pandemic Legacy, you will get lots of new cards, goals, rules stickers, characters, and other game components. There are 12 missions, and you get 2 chances to beat each. There is a deck of cards you progress through with each mission, win or lose. There are dossiers panels to open containing stickers. You will be putting stickers all over the rules, board, and cards, forever changing them. There are boxes to open during certain triggers, giving you bigger components. And after each game, win or lose, you can make choices to upgrade different things, making your team stronger. The game will tell you to destroy components, but I just saved "destroyed" components in a separate bag as mementos. This game is a one time play through, but the game is so good that it is still worth it even though it's pricey. That said, if you don't like puzzles or don't quickly adjust to change, this game is probably not for you. If you do well, the rewards will compound. If you do poorly, you get some help, but probably not enough to make the game fun for you. And if characters die, you might get a lot weaker. Also, the game is cooperative and you will need to make decisions as a group. For me, the game is fantastic, one of the best ever, but I can see how playing it with the wrong group could ruin it. Because the game is so unique and uses stickers, it's very important to read things carefully, and you will need to look up some rules clarifications online or just make judgement calls as a group. If you make a mistake, it can be impossible to reset from it. These are not reusable stickers, and they don't peel off. But you can punish or aid yourself to make up for mistakes, but agreeing on what is a fair correction is a challenge. We did screw up one big thing and caught it after a game, and then punished ourselves even harder for it. Just make sure multiple players are reading the rules and keeping an eye out for mistakes. Double and triple checking before placing stickers. The game quality is great, but it can be difficult to write on the character sheets. Some pens work better on them than others. It can be tricky to peel the stickers from their backings too, and lay them down straight. It's not for the obsessive compulsive. So far, I have played season 1 and 2. Season 1 is my favorite. The theme & gameplay is great in both. Though the artwork is better in season 2, especially the character art which is more customizable, in a post apocalyptic theme where you start on floating cities in the ocean and must discover the map as the season goes. Season 1 has the traditional Pandemic look, with the full map revealed from the start. But I felt like season 1 ended really well, taking into account your overall progress to give you a final score that was more meaningful, while season 2 pinned all your success on a final gauntlet. Season 2 had more randomness because you had to make decisions without knowing what was hidden in the map. We put off going to some places thinking we were doing ourselves a favor, but instead ended up hurting ourselves considerably. But both are great games and you could start with either. Note that season 1 and 2 come in 2 box colors each. There is no difference to the gameplay in the 2 colors. It is basically so you can play 2 campaigns simultaneously and tell them apart.
